A Type 1 Athlete

[ Edited ]

‎06-13-2012 10:00 PM - edited ‎06-13-2012 10:02 PM

G'day all

 

I'm T2 so I don't get over here often. However, as I am a Rugby League fan I thought some of you may be interested in seeing one of our local players.

 

I won't even try to explain the rules of Rugby League to Americans. Sufficient to mention some of the differences between American football and Rugby league.

 

The game only stops twice, at half-time and full time. There are no time outs although the game may be stopped by the referee temporarily for injured players to be treated, but only if where they are lying interferes with play. The coach can replace any of the 13 on-field players from four reserves during the match, but only up to ten times. Thus the Offence and Defence are the same team. No helmets and limited padding.The ball can only be passed back, not forwards. A touchdown is called a "try" and the ball must actually be touched down to score.

 

The Australian NRL is roughly equivalent to NFL or AFL. Instead of a Superbowl system we have "Origin" which is where the best players from the two major Rugby League states play three times each year. Players are selected based on their state of origin; a bit like your all-pro teams. These are considered the toughest and roughest games in Rugby League.

 

An edited version of last night's "Origin II" match is on the link below. One of the stars was Brett Stewart, who plays full-back for New South Wales, number 1 in the blue uniforms. He appears in sequences commencing at 0:20 and 2:55.

 

Brett is a type 1.

 

State of Origin II: As it happened

Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.
Type 2 Diabetes - A Personal Journey(latest: Fat: The New Health Paradigm)
Born Under a Wandering Star (Latest: Ella to Kandy, Sri Lanka)

Trisha



Trisha

IDDM (Type 1 Autoimmune) 30+ many more years ~ Currently using MDI & Minimed CGM ~
Check out my diabetes blog!

All brittle means, is that one has great fluctuations, which is pretty much hallmark for Type 1's. Some more so than others. - me

First light brings a new day, new hope, new wisdom, and a chance to start fresh again. - me

If everyone were dealt the same amount of cards, there would be no challenges in life. Challenges are part of life's lessons, to teach us to grow in all aspects, and to learn what we need to learn, to make it in this world. Life was not meant to be fair. -me

"WE, the PEOPLE....."

~ New Type 1 Info ~ Insulin, Test Strips, Lancets, and other meds ~ Kidney Damage Info ~



*****************
Sidenote to new members....please put which type of diabetes you have, in your signature area. T1's and T2's cross post on these forums, and it is imperative that we all know which type one is. This is so that no misinformation is given to anyone. Type 1 and Type 2 are two totally absolute different diseases with different causes, thus making self-management very different. Thank you!, and welcome to the forums.
*****************

‎06-14-2012 03:05 AM

just had to say this

 

i come from a small community. started playing on the varsity football(american) team in 7th grade(yes, i was on JV and V at the same time). When I started playing in college, it was strange to be asked "do you play offense or defense?".  Our school was so small that when I was in tenth grade...i never came off the field unless i was shaking and low. Was on every single possible team. Got to play rugby in college some and loved it cause it felt like highschool again.

26/m/AL. Type 1 since 10/15/01. shots till fall05, insulin pump from fall 05-fall10, now on lantus/humalog
